abstract.text: The novel coronavirus, SARS-CO V2 responsible for COVID-19 pandemic is rapidly escalating across the globe. Burn centers gearing for the pandemic must strike a balance between contributing to the pandemic response and preserving ongoing burn care in a safe and ethical fashion. The authors of the present communication represent seven burn centers from China, Singapore, Japan, Italy, Spain, the United Kingdom (UK), and the United States (US). Each center is located at a different point along the pandemic curve and serves different patient populations within their healthcare systems. We review our experience with the virus to date, our strategic approach to burn center function under these circumstances, and lessons learned. The purpose of this communication is to share experiences that will assist with continued preparations to help burn centers advocate for optimum burn care and overcome challenges as this pandemic continues.

Key lessons from centers at the tail end of the epidemic 736 surge 737 Chongqing and Shanghai are cities of the largest scale, positioned 738 relatively close to Hubei and are now well past the main surge of 739 infections. The most important lessons from their experience are 740 on the subject of big picture coordination and discipline in 741 prevention. Their remarkable success in containment should 742 motivate other centers to carefully study their approach. 743 Both cities had a centralized command structure for the 744 response to the virus which was able to direct the population 745 and coordinate city-wide clinical strategy. 746 Even though COVID-positive patients were kept out of the 747 burn service, both burn centers maintained intense and 748 meticulous precautions with great discipline. Consequently, 749 neither of these exceptionally large burn centers had a single 750 case of a COVID positive patient in their main units, preserving 751 burn center function. And importantly, burn patients who 752 were COVID-positive were successfully managed as part of the 753 COVID-positive cohort. 754 11.2. Key lessons from centers currently in the middle of the 755 surge 756 Barcelona is a large city with an advanced healthcare system. 757 And yet the surge of life-threatening COVID-19 has forced the city 758 to engage in a heroic defensive action. A key lesson to be learned 759 is that the COVID-19 surge can reach a scale and intensity that 760 few of us have ever experienced. As the surge intensifies, a 761 continuous reallocation of healthcare resources may be required. 762 This is a challenging task that should be vigorously planned now. 763 Likewise, burn center resources will be increasingly directed to 764 the COVID-19 response.
